article.title: How does JPA Security work internally?
article.para: JPA Security intercepts your action with the EntityManager. Whenever you retrieve an entity from your EntityManager, it is backed by a proxy from JPA Security and whenever you perform a JPQL-query, it is modified with additional clauses and parameters to match your security rules.

section.title: Secure entities
section.para: The proxies that are created around your entities are called SecureEntity (actually they implement an interface of the same name). This is how they behave:

listitem.para: When the entity is accessed first a check is performed, whether the current user is allowed to read the entity.

On the first access of the entity all one-to-one- and one-to-many-relations to other entities are replaced by relations to SecureEntities that back the original entities and all many-to-one- and many-to-many-relations are replaced by SecureCollections, which are explained later.

Changes to the entity are buffered and only flushed to the entity when the active transaction is committed, flush() is called on the EntityManager or a query is performed with flush-mode AUTO (which is the default). Whenever a SecureEntity flushes its changes, a check is performed before, whether the current user is allowed to update the entity.
During the flush of a SecureEntity all relations to other SecureEntities or to SecureCollections are replaced by their corresponding original.
